question: What does DBSCAN stand for?
options: Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise
Distance-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise
Density-Based Sequential Clustering of Applications with Noise
Distance-Based Sequential Clustering of Applications with Noise

question: Which parameters are required for the DBSCAN algorithm?
What is a core point in DBSCAN?
options: A point with fewer than min_samples points in its neighborhood
A point with at least min_samples points within eps distance
A point that is not assigned to any cluster
A point with the maximum distance to any other point

question: Which of the following are advantages of DBSCAN?
options: Can find clusters of arbitrary shape
Does not require the number of clusters as input

question: What happens to points that do not belong to any cluster in DBSCAN?
options: They are assigned to the nearest cluster
They are removed from the dataset

question: Which of the following are limitations of DBSCAN?
options: Difficulty in choosing eps and min_samples
Not suitable for data with varying densities
Sensitive to the choice of distance metric

question: Which library provides DBSCAN implementation in Python?
Which of the following are types of points in DBSCAN?
What is the time complexity of DBSCAN for n points?
Which of the following are true about DBSCAN?
options: It can handle noise in the data
It can find clusters of arbitrary shape
It is sensitive to the scale of features

question: What is a border point in DBSCAN?
options: A point with more than min_samples neighbors
A point within eps of a core point but with fewer than min_samples neighbors
A point not connected to any core point
A point at the centroid of a cluster

question: Which of the following can be used as distance metrics in DBSCAN?
What is the effect of increasing eps in DBSCAN?
options: More points are labeled as noise

question: Which of the following are true about the min_samples parameter?
options: It controls the minimum number of points to form a dense region
Higher values make clusters more stringent
Lower values make clusters more likely to form
It has no effect on noise points

question: What is a noise point in DBSCAN?
options: A point that is a core point
A point not reachable from any core point
A point at the center of a cluster

question: Which of the following are applications of DBSCAN?
What happens if all points are labeled as noise in DBSCAN?
options: All points are assigned to a single cluster

question: Which of the following are true about DBSCAN's ability to find clusters?
options: It can find clusters of arbitrary shape
It can miss clusters in data with varying densities
It always finds the global optimum

question: What is the role of feature scaling in DBSCAN?
options: It can significantly affect clustering results
It is used to determine min_samples

question: Which of the following are true about DBSCAN?
options: It can handle large datasets efficiently
